Abstract

Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by bacteria of the genus Brucella spp. It is cosmopolitan and rages around the Mediterranean, particularly in Algeria where it continues to wreak havoc on livestock. We report here a review on brucellosis in Algeria, where human brucellosis was already discovered in 1895 and since then it remains a major concern of health services. There is a disparity in human cases depending on the region, in fact, the most affected region is the steppe region which alone has the average incidence (cases/100,000 inhabitants) of 65.87% followed by 9.89 in North- Is according to the Ministry of Health. The prevalence of bovine brucellosis fell from 5% to 0.76% respectively in the mid-1990s and in 2014 with a delicate improvement which, after seven years of the identification and screening program as well as vaccination with the REV vaccine -1 set up by the Ministry of Health, remains unable to eradicate the disease. It should also be noted that the evolution of the number of new human cases reported is like that observed in goats, which constitute the most important reservoir of infection for humans in Algeria.

Keywords: Algeria, Bovine brucellosis, brucella, brucellosis, caprine brucellosis, human brucellosis

Evolution of animal and human brucellosis in

Algeria: a mini narrative review

Introduction

Brucellosis is an infectious zoonotic disease [[1], [2], [3]], caused by bacteria belonging to the genus Brucella [2]; Brucella abortus and Brucella melitensis are often responsible for disease in cattle and humans, respectively [4]. In cattle, the impact is economic [5] where Brucella is responsible for infertility, abortions during the last trimester of gestation, a drop in milk production and the compulsory slaughter of positive cattle [2,[5], [6], [7], [8]]. As a result, animal brucellosis impacts trade in animals and animal products [9]. Given its zoonotic aspect and faced with a multitude of transmission routes for the pathogen such as aerosols [8] and the consumption of raw milk or its derivatives [[10], [11], [12]]; brucellosis can cause sterility and arthritis in humans [[13], [14], [15]].

In Algeria, brucellosis remains a public health problem [16], where its incidence increased from 0.36 to 16.76 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in 1989 and 2011 respectively and reached 28 cases in 2010 [17]. In animals, 3799 cases of brucellosis in small ruminants (3592 goats and 207 sheep) were recorded in 2006, of which 3796 were slaughtered [17]. In cattle, brucellosis seroprevalence is estimated at 26.3% [18]. Also, Brucella has been isolated from cow's milk [19]. The number of new cases in animals is similar to that of humans, which shows the importance of the animal reservoir on public health. In addition, disease incidence in humans can provide a clue to the true disease status in animals [17]. Consequently, this animal brucellosis continues to cause considerable economic losses, particularly in terms of the slaughter of positive subjects and continues to be a source of human contamination in Algeria. This article presents an updated inventory of knowledge on human and animal brucellosis in Algeria to try to better understand the current situation by analyzing some risk factors related to the transmission of this disease in humans and animals.

Definition, distribution, and history of brucellosis

Definition

Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis that can be chronic, common to humans and animals [20,21]. It is caused by various bacterial species belonging to the genus Brucella [22]. Brucellosis remains one of the most important zoonotic diseases in the world [23]. In Algeria, it is a notifiable disease according to Executive Decree No. 95-66 of 1995 [24]. Previously, there were several names for this infection: Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Cyprus fever, Gibraltar fever and undulant fever, later called brucellosis [4].

History and distribution

Surgical assistant at the Royal Academy of Medicine in the UK, Jeffery Allen Marston, was the first to describe brucellosis as “Mediterranean relapsing gastric fever” in 1981 from his base in Malta [ [25] in [26,27]].

In 1884 the surgeon Captain David Bruce (1855–1931) ( ) [28] arrived on the island of Malta. On the island, Bruce saw firsthand an illness that caused patients' temperatures to rise overnight to 41°C and become normal during the day. This fever persists for weeks, sometimes for months and sometimes it leads to the death of the patient [29].

In 1887, while being a lieutenant-colonel and doctor in the royal army; Bruce performed autopsy samples taken from the spleens, livers and kidneys of infected British soldiers residing in Malta and discovered an organism which he called “Micrococcus melitensis”. That he isolated it from the spleens of five soldiers who died of fever in Malta and he identified it for the first time as the causative agent of brucellosis, which was later renamed “Brucella melitensis” in his honor by Meyer and Shaw. Bruce noticed that “Micrococcus” is about 3 μm in length, single or paired that this organism is Gram negative. To confirm whether this organism is the causative agent of Malta fever, Bruce infected monkeys with this organism grown in culture. Seven monkeys were infected and four died, while the other three survived but had undulant fever similar to that seen in humans. Bruce then studied tissue samples from monkeys that died, and he managed to grow the same micrococcus from their organs [[30] in [26,27,29,31,32]].

In 1895/1897, the Danish veterinarian Bernard Lauritz Frederik Bang ( ) [33] isolated microorganisms, called Bacillus abortus, from the foetus, placenta, and uterine secretions during contagious abortions of cattle [ [34] in [27,35,36], Petrović and Cvetnić, 2017 Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science, Brucellosis-the past, the present, the future 2017; 85: 012,019. IOP Publishing [37]]. In 1897, Wright and Smith proved brucellosis to be a zoonotic disease, after detecting specific antibodies to Brucella melitensis in human and animal serum agglutination tests [ [38] in [27]].

On September 23, 1905, a shipment from Malta carrying 60 goats arrived in New York. The herd was quarantined due to numerous deaths during the trip. The crew members, the expedition leader who was an agent of the U.S. Bureau of Animal Industry, and a milk-drinking woman who “escaped” from the quarantine station showed the characteristic symptoms of the “Mediterranean fever”. David Bruce had warned the American health authorities of the risk of “Mediterranean fever” by importing goats from Malta. In the same year (1905), Themistocles Zammit, a Maltese citizen and scientific member of the Mediterranean fever commission headed by Bruce, proved that the reservoir of this organism responsible for this fever was goat's milk, and in November 1906 the goats were destroyed [29,32].

Brucellosis is an infection observed all over the world and on all continents, particularly in Mediterranean countries, the Arabian Peninsula, Central and North America, Mexico, and India. This disease mainly affects low-income countries, which still suffer from significant morbidity. In developed countries, the infection has been eradicated from animals [ [32,34,39,40] In [27]].

Human and animal brucellosis has been reported for a long time in Africa, the frequency of this disease in the Maghreb has been underestimated and its epidemiological situation remains poorly documented [17]. Human brucellosis was already discovered in Algeria in 1895 at the Pasteur Institute of Algeria [41]. In 1982, a report by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) on brucellosis in the Near East declared the “probable” absence of brucellosis caused by Brucella melitensis in Algeria, Morocco and Libya, but its presence, in sporadic form, in humans and goats in Tunisia [ [42] in Benhabyles et al., 1992 Proceedings of the international seminar: Prevention of brucellosis in the Mediterranean countries [17]].

However, this epidemiological silence did not remain for long and from the mid-1980s to the beginning of the 1990s, marked by the increase in the disease in humans in the Maghreb as in Algeria [Benhabyles et al., 1992 Proceedings of the international seminar: Prevention of brucellosis in the Mediterranean countries], health authorities have been alerted to the existence of an animal reservoir [17]. Also, following the serious epidemic which struck Ghardaïa in 1984, where 600 cases were diagnosed, particular attention was paid to the disease. After Ghardaïa, the disease was then reported in other regions, such as the region of Tlemcen (1986) and the region of Sétif (1989). Cheese consumption was considered the main source of infection [Benhabyles et al., 1992 Proceedings of the international seminar: Prevention of brucellosis in the Mediterranean countries [43]; in [41]]. Serological detection of bovine brucellosis in Algeria from 1969-1976 showed an infection rate of around 12% [44]. In 1986–1989, overall seropositivity in sheep and goats was 2.18% and 12.0%, respectively. Nevertheless, the percentages of infected flocks in sheep and goat flocks were respectively 43.5% and 42% [41].

Brucellosis in humans begins with an acute debilitating infection that can become chronic with several complications [22]. The figure of 500,000 new cases each year is regularly reported by authors, but the true incidence figures would be much higher; most of the most affected countries do not have means of diagnosis and given the multitude of symptoms of brucellosis, the latter can be confused with other febrile infections [22]. This bacterium may be responsible for arthritis and sterility in humans [[13], [14], [15]].

Infections in cattle have an enormous socio-economic cost [22]. This disease has an impact on trade in animals and animal products [9], it is responsible for the drop in milk production, the slaughter of positive cattle, infertility, abortions during the last quarter of pregnancy [2,[5], [6], [7], [8]].

Microbiological characteristics of the causative agent

Brucella are gram-negative coccobacilli, measuring 0.6–1.5 μm in length and 0.5–0.7 μm in diameter [45]. The optimum temperature for growth is 34°C. Culture of Brucella is best done with blood culture systems that reduce the generation time of these germs [46]. Brucella are strict aerobic bacteria, catalase positive, oxidase positive [45]. Most strains isolated in human pathology produce urease. Due to a weak biochemical reactivity, the identification of these bacteria by the usual phenotypic methods is difficult. In addition, the use of API-NE type identification galleries can lead to false identification of Moraxella phenylpyruvica [47]. The genome of the B. melitensis 16M strain includes two circular chromosomes of 1.15 and 2.1 Mb [48]. This organization is found in most species, except for B. suis biovar 3 which has only one circular chromosome of 3.2 Mb [48].

Sources, routes of contamination and transmission of the disease

Brucellosis is above all an animal disease and domestic livestock (cattle, sheep, goats) constitute the reservoir of infection for humans [45]. Wild animals such as reindeer, caribou, bison, yak play a reservoir role in some parts of the world [49]. Finally, strains of Brucella can infect marine mammals [50]. Host specificity for each species is relative: B. melitensis infects sheep and goats, B. abortus largely dominates in cattle, B. suis is specific to pigs. These animals are often chronically infected and shed the bacteria into the environment through abortion products and milk in females, their urine, or their feces [51].

Human contracts brucellosis

Either indirectly through the digestive tract during the ingestion of dairy products (unpasteurized milk and processed products made from raw milk), and insufficiently cooked offal contaminated or by inhalation of dust or aerosol from litter containing the bacteria. Either by direct route or by cutaneous-mucous route during professional contacts (veterinarians, breeders, slaughterhouse workers, renderers) with sick animals. Abortion products, placentas, genital secretions, bedding and bacterial cultures are, along with the cattle themselves, the sources of contamination. Contamination can also occur via the respiratory route or via the conjunctival route [51,52]. There is no human-to-human contamination. Transmission to humans and the prevalence of infection worldwide are linked to dietary habits, farming methods and local sanitary measures [52]. Digestive infection predominates in countries where milk pasteurization is not systematic [50]. In these countries, digestive contamination is responsible for epidemics in cities affecting a city population that has not had contact with infected animals [53]. Contaminations in biology laboratories (laboratory technicians, biologists) represent one of the major sources of infection when handling Brucella cultures (due to the capacity of Brucella cultures to form aerosols) or when handling animal vaccines among veterinarians and breeders [51].

Symptoms and lesions of the disease in man and animals

The primary infection in humans can manifest itself in the form of mild symptoms and go unnoticed. The infection can then remain silent for several months, even several years, and reactivate during another illness or health event. Incubation after the primary infection lasts from a few days to 1 month. The disease in humans is manifested by non-specific signs ranging from isolated fever or a trivial flu-like illness to focal infections of the joints, testicles or central nervous system. Untreated, brucellosis can become chronic and be responsible for disabling joint damage in particular [53,54].

In animals, the disease is generally mild and the infected animal shows few signs [Mtui- Malamsha, 2001. Thesis. Tanzania: Sokoine University of Agriculture; Epidemiology study of brucellosis in humans and animals in Babati and Hanang districts of Tanzania and James LW 2012. Thesis. Tanzania: Sokoine University of Agriculture; The epidemiology of Human Brucellosis in Eastern -Morogoro, Tanzania]. However, it gives rise to abortions or reproductive failure. Generally, animals recover and will successfully give birth to live offspring after a first abortion, but they may continue to shed the bacteria [55]. It is the source of significant economic losses (abortions, loss of milk and dairy products) for breeders of dairy cows, sheep, goats, and pigs [56].

Situation of human and animal brucellosis in Algeria

NB: for human brucellosis, the human cases are between the year 2000 and 2015 [Bouferkas et al., 2019. End-of-studies project Institut des Sciences Vétérinaires. University of Blida; Retrospective study of human brucellosis in Algeria].

According to the Ministry of Health, Population and Hospital Reform [60], the average incidence (cases/100,000 inhabitants) of the disease in men is estimated at 7.37 in the Center- North region, 9.89 in the North-East, 4.67 North-West, 18.26 in the Sahara and 65.87 in the steppe region [ [60] in [61]]. The distribution of human brucellosis shows that the number of cases is mainly high in the steppe region compared to other regions, especially the coastal regions ( ). Among the seven wilayas recorded more than 4000 cases of human brucellosis from the year 2000 to 2015; five are in the steppe region, namely, Djelfa (14,399 cases), M'Sila (10,453 cases), Tébessa (7659 cases), Laghouat (7216 cases) and El Bayadh (5122 cases) and two other wilayas, namely; Béchar (4131 cases) and Biskra (5498 cases) [National Institute of Public Health in Bouferkas et al., 2019. End-of-study project Institute of Veterinary Sciences. University of Blida; Retrospective study of human brucellosis in Algeria]. This high number of cases in these regions could be explained by the high population concentration of small ruminants in these areas [61]. The region of the Algerian highlands are pastures used to provide food for about 16.8 million sheep and 1.6 million goats for 3 or 4 months of the year (spring). Also, in this region, more than 7.5 million people live there, of which 10% are nomads [ [62] in [63]].

The seroprevalence of human brucellosis reported in the steppe region (El Bayadh) (113 cases/100,000 inhabitants) [64] is higher than that reported by the National Institute of Public Health in 2009 in the normal population (19,4 cases/100,000 inhabitants) [ [65] in [63]].

B. melitensis biovar 3 is the most incriminated in human cases in Mediterranean countries [9,17,61]. In the steppe region, biovar 3 was previously isolated in the department of Tiaret from cow's milk and human blood [18] and it was also the only etiology of abortion associated with brucellosis in goats. in Sétif and Batna [63].

A study is carried out to evaluate the genetic diversity of the North African strains of B. melitensis biovar 3 and to search for a possible epidemiological link with the European strains. This study showed that the Algerian and European strains come together. This testifies to the existence of a circulating line resulting from the socio-historical links between Algeria and Europe [17].

Evolution of human and animal brucellosis in Algeria

Human brucellosis

In Algeria, the incidence of brucellosis in men shows an increasing trend, with values ranging from 0.36 in 1989 to 23–24.6 in 2005–2007. In the space of ten years, the incidence increased from less than 15 to 28 per 100,000 inhabitants in the year 2000 and 2010, respectively [17]. The evolution of the number of new human cases reported is similar to that observed in goats ( ), this observation highlights the impact of the animal reservoir, in particular goats, on public health [61].

Bovine brucellosis

An improvement in the health status of animal brucellosis has been observed since the implementation of the bovine brucellosis screening program where the prevalence fell from 5% to 0.76% respectively in the mid-1990s and in 2014. However, this identification and screening program remained insufficient and only covered 6% of the Algerian cattle herd [ [66] in [61]] and the status of nearly 94% of the ruminant population remains unknown and represents an enormous source of contamination for other ruminants as well as for humans. This failure of this program is due to several factors, such as the size of the areas of Algeria, the lack of means of travel and transport for the teams of veterinary services to livestock in rural and isolated areas and the low rate of compensation that does not exceed 50% [61].

Small ruminant brucellosis

With a total of 31, 483, 680 sheep and goats, small ruminant breeding is the largest animal production sector in Algeria. The breeding of these two species is intended to produce meat and milk mainly for feta cheese [61].

Brucellosis of small ruminants caused by Brucella melitensis is the most important zoonosis which poses a serious threat to public health. Campaigns based on detection, culling and eradication have been carried out against brucellosis in small ruminants in many countries [61]. Nevertheless, a similar program initiated in Algeria since 1995 failed to control brucellosis in small ruminants due to several factors mainly, the type of farming practiced [61]. In 2002 and seven years after the establishment of the screening-slaughter program, the Algerian Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MADR) conducted a survey to estimate the prevalence of brucellosis in sheep and goats, results showed a national herd prevalence of 5.68% and herd prevalence of more than 10% in the steppe region [61]. This situation prompted the Algerian State to adopt a new prophylactic measure in 2006, by vaccinating small ruminants in the steppe region with the Rev-1 vaccine, while maintaining the screening-slaughtering program in other regions [ [66] in [61]].

Between 2006 and 2013, vaccination covered 67% of the national territory (32/48 departments) where a total of 21, 036, 314 sheep and goats were vaccinated. This slightly reduces the prevalence of brucellosis in herds of small ruminants to 3.33% in 2014 [67,61]. Similarly, a study [Kardjadj and Ben-Mahdi, 2014. The “effects” of brucella Rev-1 conjunctival vaccination of sheep and goats on human and animal brucellosis in high plateaux area Algeria. Forehead. Immunol. Conference abstract: The First International Congress of Immunology and Molecular Immunopathology] revealed a significant improvement in the health situation of the disease in both species in the steppe region after eight years of the implementation of Rev-1 vaccination in 2006. The relevance of the vaccination and the eradication program put in place was revealed by Gabli et al., 2015 [63] who reported a herd prevalence of 15.84% in the unvaccinated region [61].

Risk factors for the transmission of human and animal brucellosis in humans and ruminants in Algeria

The occurrence of brucellosis in humans depends on several factors such as husbandry practices, environmental hygiene, milk processing methods and dietary habits, such as the consumption of undercooked meat products and unpasteurized dairy products [68]. Despite awareness and prophylaxis campaigns, dietary habits remain, such as remote areas, where humans live in close contact with animals [17], more than 89% of humans who contracted brucellosis drank raw milk or its derivatives, especially in the spring since it is the season of calving cows and goats and 5.4% contracted the disease during calving [18]. In Algeria, part of human brucellosis cases, estimated at 10%, were exclusively of occupational origin, while 20% of cases resulted from mixed sources [ [69] in [61]].

According to statistics from the INSP (2009), the disease is more common in men than in women, this could be linked to the profession where men are more in the health sector than women. However, for foodborne contamination, women are more exposed than men. This could be explained by the fact that in Algeria women handle food products than men. Regarding age, the disease affects all age groups, but adults are the most affected [ [69] in [61]].

Nomadism and transhumance are a way of life characterized by the permanent movement of livestock and people and therefore a lack of health service facilities, which contributes to the appearance, persistence and spread of zoonoses such as brucellosis. in humans and their livestock. The high prevalence recorded in the nomadic population could be explained by the culture, habits, and traditions of this population, in particular the ingestion of raw milk or dairy products. The consumption of raw meat (liver and spleen) and the participation of all family members in the slaughter process which exposes them to raw products and infected blood can also be incriminated [63].

Economic impact of animal and human brucellosis in Algeria

In Algeria, animal brucellosis receives public funding of 1,897,288 EUR [Akakpo et al., 2009. The impact of brucellosis on the economy and public health in Africa. OIE Conference, 71- 84], and its cost linked to the economic losses observed during the decade from 2004 to 2013 during control and surveillance programs would be nearly 2 billion dinars [Benbetka Sarah and Chebrek Ouissame, 2015. of studies-summary. National Veterinary School - Algiers.

Preliminary study of the cost estimate of brucellosis in Algeria]. Among the main effects of this disease on the herd, a ranking in descending order according to importance has been established, namely: the drop in milk production, the increase in the interval between calving, abortions, stillbirths, infertility and also other effects [Akakpo et al., 2009. The impact of brucellosis on the economy and public health in Africa. OIE Conference, 71-84]. In humans, the cost of treating a brucellosis patient is EUR 650 [Akakpo et al., 2009. The impact of brucellosis on the economy and public health in Africa. OIE Conference, 71-84]. During the period from 2002 to 2013, the cost of human brucellosis is estimated at approximately 80 million dinars [Benbetka Sarah and Chebrek Ouissame, 2015. Graduation project - summary. National Veterinary School - Algiers. Preliminary study of the cost estimate of brucellosis in Algeria].

Conclusion and perspectives

Brucellosis remains a worldwide disease today. The associated complications are very debilitating in humans, and lead to heavy economic losses, especially in animals. In this review, we note that in Algeria the evolution of the disease in humans and animals including goats is not stable especially during the last 20 years.

In the years to come and with the aim of reducing the disease, the prophylaxis program currently adopted must be improved and this depends on the identification and screening of all the national animal herd, the declaration of positive cases in in humans and in animals, the early diagnosis, something which is not always obvious given the clinical polymorphism, the effectiveness of diagnostic means, in particular those of the laboratory, the strengthening of the “screening-slaughter” control program by covering a large number of animals and improving the rate of compensation for breeders. Also, carry out field surveys to highlight the strain in question for the right choice of vaccine which will then be applied to all the national herd. Public awareness campaigns explaining to them the danger of certain daily practices, in particular the consumption of raw milk and its derivatives, are necessary. This zoonosis will persist until the animal reservoir is controlled. The control and prophylaxis of human brucellosis necessarily involves the control and prophylaxis of brucellosis in animals, a reservoir of Brucella spp.

Amezruy d beṭṭu

Anmahal n teftakt deg tegrasnawit tageldant n tujjya deg Tgelda Idduklen, Jeffery Allen Marston, d netta i d amezwaru i d-yem- meslayen ɣef tawla n Malṭa » d tawla n uradus n wagrakal » deg 1981 deg udasil-ines deg tmurt n Malṭa [[25] deg [26,27]].

Deg useggas n 1884, ameftak lqebṭan David Bruce (1855–1931) (Tugna 1) yewweḍ ɣer tegzirt n Malṭa. Deg tegzirt-nni, Sir David Bruce yiglem-d aṭṭan ixeddmen tawla yessalayen lḥamu n imuḍan deg iḍ ɣer 41°C i d-yettṣubbun deg uzal. Tawla-agi tettɣimi aṭas n ledwar, tikwal d ayyuren, tikwal daɣen tneq imuḍan [29].

Deg 1887, yella d lqebṭan u d amejjay ar yiserdasen n tgelda: Bruce ikkes-d tubbit n uksum deg uḍiḥan, tasa akked tgeẓẓal n yiserdasen igliziyen yuḍnen yemmuten yellan di Malṭa, yufa-d taɣawsa tamuddirt iwumi isemma « Micrococcus melitensis». Ikkes-itt-id deg uḍiḥan n semmus (5) n yiserdasen yemmuten s tawla n Malṭa, i tikelt tamenzut ibeggen-d anwa i d ssebba n waṭṭan-a, isyin akkin uɣalen semman-as « Brucella melitensis » ɣef yisem-is, yefka-yas isem-a Meyer akked Caw. Bruce iwala dakken « Micrococcus » yes a 3 μm di teɣzi, d ubrin ittak anzi ɣer tbaktiriyin n Gram ibaw. Iwakken ad d-yesbin akken d ssebba n temsalmit-a, Bruce yessenṭeḍ i yibkan s wayen d-ikkes deg yiserdasen yemmuten i d-isnerna deg tnaramt s uṛebbi. Ṣa (7) n yibkan uḍnen u ukuẓ (4) mmuten, kraḍ-nni yeqqimen ddren maca s tawla tikwal tettiǧhid tikwal tettenqas am tinna i walan ɣer yimdanen. Bruce seld mi d-ikkes tubbit deg uksum n yibkan yemmuten, yuɣal isenker-d deg tnaramt amikrukukus, aya yekkes-it-id deg igmanen-nsen [ [30] deg [26,27,29,31,32]].

Deg 1895/1897, amejjay n yiɣersiwen n tmurt n Danmark Bernhard Lauritz Frederik Bang (Tugna 2) yekkes-d taɣawsa tamuddirt iwumi isemma Bacillus abortus, deg umgun, tarɣudin akked waman yellan sdaxel n tarɣudin mi ɣrint aṭas n tsita deg unṭaḍ n temsalmit [[34] deg [27,35,36]], Petṛuvi c d Cvetni c, 2017 asaru n usarag: amaḍal d tussna n twennaḍt, tawla n Malṭa-izri, amha, imal 2017; 85: 012,019. Deg 1897, Wright d Smith begnen-d dakken tawla n Malṭa d aṭṭan ineṭḍen imi i d-ufan untikuren (mgal tafekka) n Brucella melitensis deg useyyi n umenṭaḍ i d-iḍerrun deg yidammen n yimdanen akked yiɣersiwen [ [38] deg [27]].

Ass n 23 ctember 1905, iruḥ uɣerrabu deg Malṭa ar Nyu Yurk yewwi 60 n tɣeṭṭen. Taqeḍ iwt-nni erran-tt weḥd-s acku aṭas i yemmuten deg yinig. Iɣallen yeṭṭfen aɣerrabu, amasay n usikel i yellan d axeddam deg lbiru n temguri n iɣersiwen n tmurt n Marikan, akked yiwet n tmeṭṭut iswan ayefki n yiwet n taɣaṭ i d-irewlen deg uɣerrabu sbanen-d akk iskanen n tawla n wagrakal. David Bruce iwelleh iɣallen n laman di Marikan ɣef waṭṭan n wagrakal i zemrent ad awint tɣeṭṭen n tmurt n Malṭa. Deg yiwen useggas (1905), Themistocles Zammit, aɣerman n Malṭa u d a eggal n tesqamut tussnant n tawla n wagrakal anda Bruce yella d imḍebber-is, ufan-d dakken ssebba tamezwarut n waṭṭan-a d ayefki n taɣaṭ, deg useggas n 1906 zlan akk tiɣeṭṭen-nni i d-wwin deg tmurt n Malṭa [29,32].

Tawla n Malṭa d tamsalmit i yellan deg umaḍal akked yimenẓawen akk, ladɣa di tmura gar teftisin n yillel agrakal, deg tzunegzirt n Wa raben, deg Marikan talemmast d ugafa, di tmurt n Miksik d Lhend. Aṭṭan-a yettnal di tuget timura tiẓawaliyin i mazal s ant anegriref ar tura s lehlak-agi. Di tmura tinesbaɣurin aṭṭan-a yettwakkes ar yiɣersiwen [ [32,34,39,40] deg [27]].

Brusiluz neɣ tawla n Malṭa n yimdanen d yiɣersiwen tettu-jerred seg zik di Tefriqt, asnagar n waṭṭan-a di tmura n Tefriqt Ugafa ur d-ittak ara tidet acku ulac tizrawin iṣeḥḥan u daɣen addad n waṭṭan ur xdimen ara aṭas fell-as tizrawin tussnanin [17]. Aya nwala-t deg unfafad i yewwten tamdint n Tɣerdayt deg 1984, anda 600 n liḥalat i d-ufan, tamuɣli syin akkin twelleh ɣer waṭ- ṭan-a. Seld Taɣerdayt, aṭṭan-a ufan-t-id i temnaḍin nniḍen, am temdint n Tlemsan (1986) akked temnaḍt n Ṣṭif (1989). Tiffin n tawla n Malṭa n yizgaren deg yidammen di Lezzayer 1969-1976 tbeggen-d aktamur i yellan gar 12% [44]. Deg 1986-1989, amur n wulli akked tɣeṭṭen yes an tabaktirit neɣ s eddan aṭṭan-a yella s uḍfar di 2,18% ar 12,0%. Maca ilaq ad nẓer aktamur n tqeḍ iwin n wulli akked tɣeṭṭen yes an tamsalmit-agi illa gar 43,5% ar 42% [41].

Tawla n Malṭa ɣer umdan tbeddu s temsalmit taruradt, tettbeddil, tezmer ad tuɣal d tin yezgan s waṭas n tmukrisin [22]. Ar umḍan, ugar n 500,000 n tejṛutin timaynutin yal aseggas u imeskaren zgan ttawin-ten-id, maca ayen illan di tidet n tejṛutin timaynutin illa ugar ɣef wayen nsell: tuget n tmura yennul waṭṭan-a d timura ur nes i ara ttawilat n usennefru u daɣen acḥal n limarat i tes a temsalmit n tawla n Malṭa, imi ttemcabin akk yiskanen-is ishel ad tɣelḍeḍ akked temsalmiyin ixeddmen tawla [22]. Tabaktirit-agi tezmer ad texdem tamsalmit n texlifin akked t iqert ar umdan [[13], [14], [15]]. Tamsalmit ɣer yizgaren tes a azal di tdamsa n tmetti meqqren [22]. Aṭṭan-a yettnal tanezzut n yiɣersiwen akked yifuras i d-yusan seg-sen [9], irennu yesseɣlay tuẓga n uyefki, timezliwt n yizgaren is an tabaktirit deg yidammen-nsen, ti iqert, aɣray deg ukraḍyur aneggaru n tadist [2,[5], [8]].

Tulmist n tbaktirit i d-ixeddmen aṭṭan-a

Tibaktiriyin n Brucella d tibelɣezfanin n Gram ibaw, asket-nsent 0,6–1,5 μm di teɣzi d 0,5–0,7 μm di tehri [45]. Taẓɣelt tamec- ṭuḥt n unerni d 34 °C. Aṛebbi n tbaktiriyin n Brucella yettili igerrez daxel n yinagrawen n uṛebbi s yidammen acku isenqas akud n tsuta n yimikruben-agi [46]. Brucella d tibaktiriyin yettidiren kan anda yella uzwu, kaṭalaz ilaw, Uksidaz ilaw [45]. Tuget n ccetlat i d-yettwakksen deg waṭṭanen n yimdanen xeddment-d Uriyaz. Ɣef tsedmirt tasnudrant d takrurant ur d-nettban ara akken iwata, tifin n tbaktiriyin-agi iw er s tarrayin ssexdamen yal ass. Yerna, aseqdec n wallalen n tifin n tawsit API-NE tikkwal isseɣlaḍ i tifinn.

Moraxella phenyl pyruvica [47]. Ajinum n ccetla B. Melitensis 16M, is a sin ikrumuzumen ubrinen n 1,15 ar 2,1 Mb [48]. Tuddsa-yagi nettaf-itt deg tuget n ccetlat, anagar tin n B. suis biovar 3 i yes an yiwen n ukrumuzum ubrin n 3,2 Mb [48].

Aɣbalu, iberdan n unṭaḍ d usenṭeḍ n waṭṭan

Tawla n Malṭa d aṭṭan n yiɣersiwen send ad yili d aṭṭan n lmal ttṛebbin (izgaren, ulli, tiɣeṭṭen) u d a win n temsalmit ar umdan [45]. Iɣersiwen iweḥciyen tarandus, tizerzert mm tqacuct, aramul n umadaɣ, aramul n yideflawen ttilin d ssebba n waṭṭan deg kra n yimḍiqen deg umaḍal [49]. Kra n ccetlat n Brucella zemrent ad nnalent kra n yisuṭṭaḍ n yilel [50]. Tella tmuzzegt n inebgi i yal ccetla maca ma c ci d asaḍuf: B. meli-tensis tessenfufud ulli d tɣeṭṭen, B. abortus d nettat i yeqwan ar yizgaren, B. suis d imeẓli i yilfan. Iɣersiwen-a ttaḍnen aṭṭan yettuɣalen yezga s umata u ttḍeggiren-d tibaktiriyin i twen-naḍt am umgun ma yeɣri-d, ayefki ar testan, ibeccan d leɣbar [51].

Amdan yettaṭṭaf-d tawla n Malṭa

Yezmer ad yili s ubrid arusrid deg u ebbuḍ-is ma ye c ca tagella neɣ ifuras n uyefki (ayefki ur yepasturizin ara d yifuras i d-yekkan deg-s ma ur wwin ara), d tkerciwin ur newwi ara akken iwata neɣ asnuffes n uzwu akked takka yes an tibaktiriyin. Yezmer ad yili s ubrid usrid s uglim mi ara yennal imeḍqan am yisirew (amejjay n yiɣersiwen, afellaḥ, ixeddamen n yisezlayen, wid yeṭṭummun, …) n lmal yuḍnen, amgun mi ara teɣri tfunast, tarɣudin, aman i d-yettekken deg ddwaxel, tussut am uhicur i ttessun i lmal llant deg-s tbaktiriyin d ssebba n unṭaḍ. Anṭaḍ izmer daɣen ad yili s usnuffes neɣ deg wallen [51,52]. Amdan ur yessenṭaḍ ara i umdan. As eddi n tbaktirit ar umdan d uktamur n temsalmit deg umaḍal qqnen ɣer tannumi di tgella, d wamek ttṛebbin lmal d tmella tadawsant deg umḍiq-nni [52]. Tamsalmit i d-ittekken deg iẓerman teqwa deg tmura anda apasturizi n uyefki ur yelli ara [50]. Di tmura-yagi anṭaḍ yettuɣal d tasakrart di temdinin anda ur myagaren ara lɣaci d yiɣersiwen yuḍnen [53]. Anṭaḍ deg tnarament n tesnudert (imesnuddiren, imaz-zagen n tnaremt) d ssebba tameqqrant n lehlak mi ara ttnalen tihras n Brucella (acku tihras n Brucella zemrent ad ddunt deg uzwu) neɣ mi ara ttnalen tagezzayt n yiɣersiwen ar yimejjayen yiɣersiwen d yifellaḥen [51].

Iskanen d tfidiwin ɣer umdan d uɣersiw

Tazwara n temsalmit ar umdan tezmer ad d-tbin s kra n iskanen ur ttwa qalen ara, izmer ad t eddi war ma ifaq-as. Tamsalmit tezmer ad teqqim d tasusamt kra n wayyuren, tikwal kra n yiseggasen, tettaki-d ma yella umdan yuḍen s waṭṭan nniḍen neɣ tenqes tezmert-is. Tiɣimit n tbaktirit deg tfekka deg tazwara n temsalmit tett eṭṭil gar kra n wussan d wayyur. Aṭṭan imir-nni ar umdan ittban-d s kra n yiskanen ur nettwa qal ara am tawla d tusut ittelḥaq arma d tamsalmit n texlafin, ad bezgent akk, d ubzag n yiwetman, abzag n wadif d yiẓuran deg uqerruy. Ma ur tdawa ara, tawla n Malṭa tettuɣal d aṭṭan yezgan anda txeddem abzag ladɣa deg texlifin [53,54].

Ar yiɣersiwen, aṭṭan di tuget ur yew ir ara, aɣersiw yuḍnen yesbanay-d kan kra n yiskanen [Mtwi-Malamca, 2001. Agemmir. Ṭanzanya: Tasdawit Ṣukwin n Tfellaḥt; Tazrawt tussna n waṭ- ṭanen n Tawla n Malṭa ɣer yimdanen d yiɣersiwen di Babati d temnaḍt n Hanang i Ṭanzanya akked James LW 2012. Agemmir. Ṭanzanya: Tasdawit Ṣukwin n Tfellaḥt; Tussna n waṭṭanen n yimdanen n tawla n Malṭa deg Usamar-Muṛuguru, Ṭanzanya]. Maca tesseɣray tistan, tettiw ir tuṭṭfa deg ttemkina d tarrawt. Di tuget, iɣersiwen ḥellun, arnu tafunast yeɣrin tet-tuɣal tettarew, maca zemren ad ttḍeggiren tibaktiriyin [55]. Di ssebba n usruḥu adamsan meqqren (aɣray, ɣelluy n tuẓẓga n uyefki d yifuras-is) i yifellaḥen n testan tuẓẓga, n wulli, d tɣeṭṭen akked yilfan [56].

Anerni n tawla n Malṭa n yimdanen d yiɣersiwen di Lezzayer
